sect1.title: Working with Service Call StatisticsService Call Statistics
sect1.para: Service call Statistics typically deals with questions such as:

listitem.para: What was/is the total loadtotal load on our system?
What services were called when, how often, by whom?
What was the system performance performanceperformance of the system, i.e. the response time to these services?
Have the been errors while processing the service calls? How many? When?

sect1.para: The Service Call Statistics flavor is ideally suited for answering those questions. It can be initiated by
sect1.itemizedlist:
choosing appropriate log files in the Log File Selection Dialog (see ). Such log files typically contain one or more log lines per service call, which contain a time stamp, the name of the service, the response time, and optionally the user who invoked the service and a return code.
choosing a log parser configuration with a Service Calls and Response Times Parser Type.
pressing the ApplyApply button.

sect2.title: The service call statistics panelservice call statistics panel
sect2.para: A service statistics panel will appear. An example is schon in . The panel lists all the services that have been called together with some important statistical numbers. All these numbers consider the full observation time period of all monitored log files. They are:

listitem.para: Shows how many times a specific service was called in total.

Show the number of service calls of a specific service that returned with an error code.
This column is only displayed if the active log parser configuration contains a Value representing OKValue representing "OK". See .
The number of service calls, divided by the observation period, i.e. the mean number of service calls per minute.
The mean response times. Calculated as the sum of all response times divided by the number of service calls.

The median of the response times. Half of the observed service call took longer, half of them took shorter to respond than this value. The median is less sensitive to extreme values than the mean response time: A few service calls with very long response times can lead to elevated mean response times, but have less influence onto the median.
The 90% percentile of the response times. 10% of all service calls took shorter than this value to respond.

sect2.para: The row named "totaltotal" considers all service calls. The rows that are labeled with a service name represent the statistics of a specific service.

figure.title: The service call statistics panelservice call statistics panel

sect2.para: A user can interact with the service call statistics panel in various ways. By clicking a row in the service table, he can bring up a Service Call Detail window will pop up and show the individual service calls. One by row. See .

figure.title: The service call details windowservice call details window

sect2.para: The right half of the service statistics table is used for the configuration of a service scatter plot: The checkboxes define what details will be shown in the plot. The meanings of the checkboxes are:

listitem.para: When enabled, every service single service call of a specific service is represented by a dot.
When enabled, a line which represents the number of service calls per second is displayed. This average value will be calculated once per minute.
When enabled, a line representing the mean response times (per minute) is displayed.
When enabled, a line representing the median response times (evaluated once per minute) is displayed.

sect2.para: The color column allows the assignment of specific colors to specific services. When clicked, a color chooser dialog is brought up. The Statistics Magnification FactorsStatistics Magnification Factors allows an artificial steepening of the "Mean" and "Median" lines by multiplying the according values with a factor. This can be useful, when those lines are hard to see behind the dots of the scatter plots.

The column widthcolumn width of the table can be adjusted with the mouse. Click and drag the right border of a column header cell for that purpose. Table columns can be sorted by left-clicking the column header cell.

sect2.title: The user paneluser panel
sect2.para: When the configured log parser is specifying a user field, an additional panel, the "user panel" () is created by &logtracker;. The user panel has similar fields as the service call statistics panel, but it organizes the numbers along the users instead of the services. The logtracker user can choose not to consider service calls from specific tracked users in the service call scatter plot by unchecking the checkboxes in the user panel.

sect2.title: The Service Call Scatter PlotService Call Scatter PlotScatter Plot
sect2.para: When the user presses the Apply button of either the service call statistics panel or the user panel the service call scatter plot will be displayed. An example of such a plot is shown in . Service call of various services are indicated as colored dots colored dots. The position of the dot on the horizontal axis indicates the time of the occurrence time occurrence of the service call. The position on the vertical axis represents the response timeresponse time. Erroneous callsErroneous calls are represented by a small cross sign. Statistical values, such as mean, median and number of calls per minute are shown as colored lines.

In order to get more information about a specific data point just hover the mouse close to it. As a consequence cross hairscross hairs will focus the closest data pointclosest data point and a tool tip will show some information about it.
The user can zoom to to any section he likes. To zoomzoom in, just use the mouse to select a rectangle. ()
To zoom out open a context menucontext menu by right clicking on the plot. The context menus also presents various other options.()
